title: dbe - data schema for building envelopes
description: This data schema allows to exchange detailed data about building envelopes. For each data point, there is exactly one key in the schema to make it easy to develop software which interprets the data correctly. If you should miss any key, please propose it at the website to be included in the next updata of this schema.

internationalString.description: It has been decided to keep everything in English so far. If other languages are included at a later stage, this structure makes it easy.

webAddress.description: In extension to the validation keyword `hostname`, a `webAddress` includes a `scheme` like https and possibly a `path` like /folder/item. TODO: Add an additional regex which checks whether the uri contains a `hostname`.

meterWithoutUncertainty.description: Meter is the SI unit for length. MeterWithoutUncertainty is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

items.description: A building envelope component can be a plain material, a layer in a stack of layers of a unit including frame effects. While some components are used e.g. only as materials, other components can be used in several categories.
Components of the category material can have the subcategories of this array which further specifies the material.
Components of the category layer can have the subcategories of this array which further specifies the layer.
Components of the category unit can have the subcategories of this array which further specifies the unit.

version.title: This section provides definitions about a version of a component.

name.description: If the version of the component has a specific name or version number, it can be entered here.

explanation.description: Here the version can be described in free text.

manufacturer.description: The URI and description of the manufacturer of the component

developer.description: The URI and description of the institution or person which developed the component

constants.title: For one dataset, the constants of the component stay the same while the variables may change between different data points.

geometry.title: This section defines the geometry of the component which can either be an assembly or a single component.

airPermeability.description: The air permeability defines how easy air can flow through the component.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the component.

cutOff.description: The cutoff angle is an angle above which the incident radiation cannot cause glare.

chemicalElements.description: In this array, the most important chemical elements can be named by the two letters of the periodic table of elements.

material.description: If the component is a material, the material-specific constants can be named here.

layer.description: If the component is a layer, the layer-specific constants can be named here.

unit.description: If the component is a unit, the unit-specific constants can be named here.

uri.description: This URI identifies the method which is specified below.

valid.description: Here you can define since when the method is valid and until when. This can be helpful for example when a regulation or standard changes.

available.description: Here you can define since when the method has been available and until when. This can be helpful for example when a method is shared considerably later than when it was created. You can also use it to define that the method may have been available for a long time even though it may not be valid for the whole time of its availability.

calculation.description: Here you can define the method either as code or as executable.

standard.title: Standards are a special kind publications. Therefore their data structure is different from publications.

identifier.description: A standard may be named `ISO 52022-1` or `ASTM E2387`. While `ISO` and `ASTM` are the abbreviations for the standardizers, `52022` and `2387` are the main numbers. `E` is the prefix and `1` is the postfix which may indicate for example a part number. This classification facilitates the search, because there are multiple ways to refer to a standard.

year.description: It is important to define the year in which the standard was issued because there can be relevant updates of one standard.

standard.description: `ISO 52022` is an example of the abbreviation of a standardizer and the main number of the identifier.

dimensions.title: The geometric dimensions refer to the installation of the component in a building envelope. The dimensions can be used to define a bounding box which includes all parts of the component. If a component can be installed in different ways, more than one set of dimensions can be defined.

height.description: The height of the component along the vertical axis of the building envelope.

width.description: The width of the component along the horizontal axis of the building envelope.

depth.description: The depth of the component along the axis perpendicular to the building envelope.

basics.title: This section presents definitions to describe the geometry of a component.

centerOfGravity.description: Definition of the center of gravity of the component

dimensions.description: Height, width and depth of the component.

coordinateSystem.description: Definition of the coordinate systems to which the other coordinates refer to.

bodies.description: This array lists all the bodies of which the component consists.

file.description: Instead of or in addition to the keys above, a file can be used to define the geometry of the component.

LOD.title: The Level of Development or Level of Detail (LOD) is used to describe how accurate the reality is modelled. As geometry/LOD refers to geometry, it is sometimes also called Level of Geometry.

items.description: This integer indicates the LOD according to the definition of the reference below.

reference.description: This reference defines the LOD which is indicated above.

point.title: This section defines a point according to the definition of a coordinate system elsewhere.

coordinateSystem.title: Definition of the coordinate system of the data set

reference.description: The coordinate system needs to be well defined. If no suitable reference exists, please create a new publication in the database.

items.description: Often, a right-handed cartesian coordinate system is used.

NURBS.title: A non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) surface is a very general way to define a surface. It is created by two NURBS curves.
A non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) is a very general way to define a curve.

degree.description: The degree of a NURBS curve defines the polynomial degree of the basis functions of the curve. For degree=1, the curve is a linear interpolation between the control points.

controlPoints.title: The control points have a strong influence on the shape of the curve.

items.description: If the curve is 3D, the 3D points are appropriate. For 2D curves, the value for the z-axis should be 0.

weights.description: The weight of a control points determines its influences on the shape of the curve.

controlPoints.description: The number of control points plus the degree plus 1 has to be equal to the number of knots.

items.description: Each knot is a number which is either equal or larger than the preceding knot. Although usually the control points are used to shape the curve, the knots could also be used for this purpose. The first and last knot are usually repeated so that the curve ends exactly at these points.

knots.description: The number of control points plus the degree plus 1 has to be equal to the number of knots.

brep.title: Boundary representation (brep) defines a component by the surfaces between solid and non-solid.
brep.description: This array list all surfaces between solid and non-solid of the component.

assembly.title: Components can either consist of one element or of an assembly of elements. This section is used to define assemblies of elements.

items.description: Each item represents the geometry of one element of the assembly

constants.title: This section collect all constants which are specific for components of the category materials.

possiblePositions.description: PossiblePositions defines where the material can be used.

constants.title: This section collect all constants which are specific for components of the category layers.

possiblePositions.description: PossiblePositions defines where the layer can be used.

items.description: The orientation axis is important for example for venetian blinds.

slat.title: For example venetian blinds consist of many slats. This section is used to define constants for such slats.

pitch.description: Pitch is the distance between the rotation axis' of two neighbouring slats.

crownHeight.description: When a slat lies on a horizontal surface, the Crown Height is the distance between this surface and the heighest points of the slats.

oneOf.description: Usually, the shape of a slat is best described by a 2D curve of its cross section.
If the shape of the slats needs to be defined in 3D, a surface can be used.

tilt.description: For horizontal slats, the slat tilt angle is measured from the horizontal plane. 0Â° means fully open slats and 70Â° almost closed slats.

maximumClosing.description: The maximum closing angle is the highest possible slat tilt angle, typically because the slats tough each other.

constants.title: This section collect all constants which are specific for components of the category units.

gaps.title: The gaps for example between a blind and the frame can be important for example regarding glare.

dTop.description: dTop is usually a distance at the top of the unit, but is defined exactly in the reference below.

dGlass.description: dGlass is usually a distance to the glass pane, but is defined exactly in the reference below.

reference.description: This reference defines all parameters of this object.

source.title: The source data is the data which has been the starting point and on which a method was applied by the creator of the new data set.

uri.description: Each source data is identified exactly by an URI for traceability.

name.description: A data set can have a name.

explanation.description: This string can explain the source data for humans.

origin.title: Origin can be used to define how the data was created.

creator.description: The creator of the new dataset is identified here.

method.description: The method which has been applied by the creator on the source data is identified here. This method may be a combination of submethods.

source.description: The source data has been the starting point for the creator. If the method is a measurement, there may be no source data.

database.description: The database, where the source data and the method can be found, is identified here.

basics.title: The array is used to define sets of optical data.

uri.description: An optical data set is identified by a URI.

name.description: If the optical data set has a name, it can be indicated here.

explanation.description: This string can explain humans the optical data set.

origin.description: For traceability, the origin of the data can be defined.

approvals.description: If the optical data is approved by stakeholders, a signature can be provided.

created.description: When the optical data was created.

valid.description: From when and until when the data is valid.

constants.description: Parameters which do not change during the individual measurements can be indicated here as constants. This reduces the file size.

file.description: The optical data can be provided as a file. If the data is provided as a file and as explicit values below, than it MUST be the same data only in different formats. If one data is derived from another data, it MUST be stored as separate items in the array optical/basics and origin SHOULD be used to identify the method of derivation.

dataPoint.title: This section provides a list of all data points of this optical data.

items.title: Each optical data point consists of a definition of the incident radiation, the variables of the component, the emergent rediation and the optical results.

incidence.description: This section defines the incident radiation on the component.

variables.description: This section defines the variable which change between some data points. Parameters which stay constant can be indicated above constants in order to reduce the file size.

emergence.description: This section defines the radiation which emerges from the component.

results.description: Results can be for example the transmittance and the reflectance.

direction.title: This section defines a direction for example of the radiation on a sample. The array offers different ways of describing the direction, for example by two angles.

polar.description: In the spherical coordinate system, the polar angle is measured from a fixed axis such as the z-axis of a cartesian coordinate system.

azimuth.description: In the spherical coordinate system, the polar angle is measured from orthogonal projextion of the direction on a reference plane such as the plane between the x- and y-axis of a cartestian coordinate system.

xz.description: If the z-axis is normal to the building envelope and the x-axis directs for example vertically upwards in a facade,then the angle xz is measured from the z-axis towards the x-axis. 80Â° is then from the facade almost vertically upwards and -10Â° means from the facade downwards, but almost horizontal.

yz.description: If the z-axis is normal to the building envelope, the x-axis directs for example vertically upwards in a facade and the y-axis is horizontal in an right-handed coordinate system, then the angle yz is measured from the z-axis towards the y axis. From the facade looking to the exterior, 80Â° means a direction far right, almost parallel to the facade. -10Â° means from the facade to exterior slightly left, but almost perpendiculat to the facade.

incidence.description: If the sample has a rotational symmetry, then the incidence angle is sufficient to define the direction.

items.description: Nearnormal means a direction almost perpendicular to the sample surface. Hemispherical means all directions into the hemisphere above the sample surface, for example when there is the same irradiance from all directions. Diffuse means all directions except the nearnormal direction. Therfore, the hemispherical transmittance is always equal to the nearnormal transmittance plus the diffuse transmittance.

formatting.description: The definition of the format of the array below needs to specify how the items of the array can be interpreted as a list of directions. For example, the format can define that the list consists of pairs of polar and azimuth angles.

items.description: In order to reduze the size of the data, multiple directions can be entered as an array.

polarisation.title: Polarization is a characteristic of radiation which can influence the transmittance and the reflectance. Radiation can be polarized linearly or circular.

s.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field perpendicular to the plane of incidence of the radiation on the sample. s is usually between 0 and 1. Only in raw data there may be exceptions because of the uncertainty. However, s can never be below 0-uncertainty or larger than 1+uncertainty.

p.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field parallel to the plane of incidence of the radiation on the sample. p is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

l.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field rotating in a left-hand sense with respect to the direction of radiation. l is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

r.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field rotating in a right-hand sense with respect to the direction of radiation. r is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

wavelengths.title: This section offers three options to define the wavelength of radiation: either as a single wavelength, as an array of wavelenghts or as an integral over many wavelengths.

wavelength.description: A single wavelength in nanometers. If necessary, the uncertainty can be defined under `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/bandwidth`.

items.description: An array of wavelengths, each in nanometers. If the uncertainty is identical, it can be defined under `#/definitions/wavelength/range/bandwidth`. If the uncertainty is not identical and relevant, the array should not be used.

This flag indicates that an integral over many wavelenthgs is considered here. Under `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/spectrum`, the spectrum can be specified over which the integral is calculated.

range.title: The range can either define the bandwidth or amplification factor of measuring a single wavelength or an entire spectrum of wavenlengths which is measured at the same time.###
